content: Patrick Crusius, the man who killed 23 people at an El Paso Walmart in 2019 is sentenced to 90 consecutive life sentences, the second longest amount of life sentences in the United States behind Terry Nichols, the perpetrator of the Oklahoma City bombing in 1995.
Meta Platforms launches Threads as a direct competitor to Twitter.
Actress Allison Mack is released from prison early, after serving two years for her role in the NXIVM sex-trafficking cult.
A mass shooting takes place in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, killing five and injuring two. The suspect was arrested later that day.
A mass shooting takes place in Baltimore, Maryland, killing two and injuring twenty-eight.
Apple Inc. closes with a market capitalization above $3 trillion for the first time, becoming the only public company to do so as of yet.
The Skyline light rail formally opens in Honolulu, Hawaii.

The Supreme Court rules 6–3 in 303 Creative LLC v. Elenis that the First Amendment prohibits states from forcing website designers to create designs they disagree with. The decision is seen as a victory for religious conservatives and free speech but a setback for LGBT+ rights.
The Supreme Court rules 6–3 in Biden v. Nebraska that the HEROES Act does not grant the president the right to forgive student debts.
Mike Pence makes a surprise visit to Ukraine, meeting with Zelenskyy and touring both Kyiv and Iprin.
